fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Statistics at UC Berkeley is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of statistical theory and methods, as well as the ability to apply statistical knowledge to real-world problems. The program emphasizes the development of critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills. Students learn to collect and analyze data, make informed decisions, and effectively convey their findings.
shortProgramDescription: The Statistics B.S. at UC Berkeley prepares students for careers in data analysis, research, and academia by providing a strong foundation in statistical theory, methodology, and application.
classHighlights: Students take a series of core courses that introduce them to the fundamental concepts of probability, statistics, and data analysis, including Statistics 134 (Concepts of Probability) and Statistics 135 (Concepts of Statistics).

The program includes a range of upper-division courses that cover advanced topics in statistical theory and methodology, such as Statistics 150 (Stochastic Processes) and Statistics 153 (Introduction to Time Series).

Students also have the opportunity to explore specialized areas, including Data Science, Computational Statistics, and Statistical Theory, through elective courses like Statistics 159 (Data Science with Python) and Statistics 201A (Introduction to Theoretical Statistics).
learningOutcomes: Understand the principles of statistical inference and data analysis.
Apply statistical knowledge to real-world problems.
Develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
Analyze and interpret data using various statistical techniques.
additionalInformation: The Statistics B.S. program at UC Berkeley is designed to be completed in four years. Students are advised to consult with departmental advisors to ensure they meet the major requirements and to plan their course schedule accordingly.
